Award.AwardTitle: Functional Analysis of cilia in Hedgehog signaling and Gli activity regulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of animals ranging from flat worms and fruit flies to humans relies on communications between cells mediated by Hedgehog (Hh) family of signal proteins. The primary cilia, tiny 'hairs' on the surface of most of our cells, are needed for cells to respond to Hh, but it remains unclear how they achieve this important function. This project focuses on Gli2, which turns on gene expression in response to Hh. First, the PI will take a molecular approach to test the hypothesis that the transportation of Gli2 into the cilia share the same mechanism used for its transportation into the nucleus. Subsequently, the PI will perform a structure/function analysis to define amino acids in Gli2 protein critical for its ciliary localization. Finally, the PI will create a genetically engineered mouse that produces a Gli2 protein incapable of entering the cilia. Using this mouse, the PI will test the hypothesis that Gli2 activity is turned on specifically in the cilia. Recent reports linked the cilia to many other signal proteins (e.g. Wnt, Bmp, PDGF etc); hence this research will not only advance understanding of how Hh regulates cell behavior through cilia-based signaling, but also provide more general insight into how cilia regulate information flow to ensure normal development of an animal.

The integration of research and education will be achieved by applying the research material to undergraduate teaching, encouraging undergraduate students to participate in lab research and providing opportunities for graduate students to be involved in teaching activities. Female and minority students will be recruited to participate in this project through NASA-sponsored programs. Finally, the PI will be actively involved in outreach activities such as participating in Pennsylvania Junior Academy of Science activities (K-12 education) and Upward-bound programs for first-generation, economically-challenged students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to understand the roles of the cilia in the activation of the Gli proteins. Gli proteins regulate gene expression in response to signaling proteins called the Hedgehog proteins. Gli proteins were found at the tip of the cilia, “hair-like” extensions of the cell surface. Significantly, loss of Gli proteins and lack of the cilia lead to similar early death of mammalian embryos. One question that was addressed in this project was: Do Gli proteins need to be at the tip of the cilia to be activated? Others had attempted to address this question in cultured cells, but overproduction of Gli proteins overrode normal regulation and made their results inconclusive. To answer this question properly, a genetic method was used to block Gli2 (one of the Gli proteins) from entering the cilia in genetically modified mouse embryos. The resulting mouse embryos exhibit the same developmental defects as those with the complete loss of the Gli2 gene, suggesting that being able to reach the tip of the cilia is essential for the function of Gli2 and the normal development of a mouse embryo. Interestingly, another Gli family member, Gli1, appeared to be partially active in cells without cilia. Further research indicated that it somehow responded to Hedgehog outside of the cilia, a phenomenon that will continue to be pursued in the future.

Another component of the project was the investigation of the mechanisms regulating the entrance of Gli proteins into the cilia. The results from this project showed that multiple positions in the middle part of the Gli2 protein were important for this event. Others have shown that the cilia entry and nuclear entry shared similar mechanisms among certain proteins. However, disrupting the nuclear entry of Gli2 did not appear to change its cilia-tip localization, suggesting additional mechanisms may also be used in the cilia entry of Gli2.

This project resulted in the publication of one research paper in Development, one review article in Seminars of Cell and Developmental Biology and two Book chapters. A second research paper is under review for publication. These publications have received 6 citations by November 2018 according to Thomson Reuters Web of Science.

This project has greatly benefited the scientific field. A clear piece of evidence is the distribution of the reagents generated from this project to 68 labs in at least 9 countries.

This project enabled the training of one PhD student, one master student and seven undergraduate students. All were females and two were under-represented minority students.
